source: Anyone who has ever got worked up because the car's sat-nav is showing a green field instead of a bypass knows that.
translation_clean:
Translate the following text from en to de: Anyone who has ever got worked up because the car's sat-nav is showing a green field instead of a bypass knows that. The same goes for those who have been in the traffic jam and had no idea why they were stuck behind a big truck.
A new study shows that people with high levels of stress are more likely to get stuck in traffic jams, which can cause them to feel worse about their work.
The researchers found that people who experienced stress were more likely to be late at work due to traffic congestion than those who did not experience stress.
The study was conducted by psychologists at the University of California, San Diego, and involved 104 participants.
They measured levels of stress using questionnaires and then asked participants to estimate how long it would take them to travel between two points on a map, taking into account traffic conditions.
The results showed that individuals who scored higher on the questionnaire indicating stress also estimated longer travel times.
This finding suggests that stress may contribute to poor time management skills and could lead to increased absenteeism or reduced productivity.
It's important to note that this is an observational study and does not prove causation, but it raises some interesting questions about the relationship between stress and workplace performance.
For example, if
reference: Das kennt jeder, der sich schon mal aufregen musste, weil das Auto-Navi statt einer Umgehungsstraße eine grüne Wiese anzeigte.

source: The historical maps of the digital BayernAtlas, an offering from the State Government's Geoportal Bayern, are anything but up-to-date – and yet it is precisely for this reason that they are so informative.
translation_clean:
The digital BayernAtlas provides a comprehensive overview of Bavaria's history through its historical maps, which have been updated regularly since 2017. This means that you can view events from the Middle Ages right up until modern times with ease.
In contrast, the paper map shows only the most recent years, and thus fails to provide a full picture of Bavarian history.
The interactive maps on the BayernAtlas website allow users to zoom in or out, and select different scales to explore various aspects of Bavarian history. They also enable users to compare the current situation with past events by clicking on specific points on the map.
Furthermore, the BayernAtlas offers detailed information about each event, including dates, locations, causes, and consequences. This makes it easy for researchers to conduct their work more efficiently and accurately.
In summary, the historical maps on the BayernAtlas are not just outdated; they are also very useful because they offer a comprehensive view of Bavarian history
reference: Die historischen Landkarten des digitalen Bayern-Atlases, ein Angebot des Geoportals Bayern der Staatsregierung, sind alles andere als aktuell - doch gerade deshalb sehr aufschlussreich.

source: Even if the French troops finally retreated with the Treaty of Lunéville from 9th February 1801: it was the current neighbours who had the idea to create a comprehensive map of Bavaria.

Translate the following text from en to de: Even if the French troops finally retreated with the Treaty of Lunéville from 9th February 1801: it was the current neighbours who had the idea to create a comprehensive map of Bavaria. In fact, it was not only the first comprehensive map but also the most detailed and accurate one.
The map is an important source for understanding the development of Germany in the period between 1756 and 1824. The map shows all the states that existed at the time, as well as the territories of Austria, Prussia and Sardinia. It even includes some details on the population density of the regions, which are based on actual data.
This map has been preserved by the National Library of Bavaria since its creation in 1801. It has never been sold or lost, and remains in good condition today. The original map can be found in the library's archives, while copies have been made available for public use.
The map itself consists of two parts: the top part showing the territory of Bavaria and the bottom part showing the administrative division of Bavaria. This arrangement allows users to compare the territorial boundaries with their administrative divisions.
In addition to its historical significance,

source: The bombs of the Allies tore many holes in the city centre in December 1944.
translation_clean:
Translate the following text from en to de: The bombs of the Allies tore many holes in the city centre in December 1944. But this is not a story about those bombs, but about something else entirely.
The first bomb was dropped on the German-occupied district of Vienna and hit a church. It killed one person inside, two others were injured by shrapnel and another died later as a result of injuries sustained that day.
In response to this attack, an additional 20 bombs were dropped on the same area. A few days later, another group of 50 bombs fell on the same target. This time, no-one was hurt or even slightly wounded. After the war, it was found out that these attacks had been carried out by British Special Air Service (SAS) troops disguised as civilians.
This incident occurred during the final weeks of the war in Europe. The bombing campaign against Vienna continued until May 1945 when the last Allied bomb fell.
The second part of the story concerns the aftermath of the bombings. Many people fled their homes because they feared for their safety. Some chose to move into more remote areas of the city while others sought refuge elsewhere. As a result, some neighborhoods became uninhabitable and had to
reference: Die Bomben der Alliierten rissen im Dezember 1944 viele Löcher in die Innenstadt.

source: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has put out an alert for people of color traveling to Missouri because of the state's discriminatory policies and racist attacks.
translation_clean:
Translate the following text from en to de: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has put out an alert for people of color traveling to Missouri because of the state's discriminatory policies and racist attacks. The NAACP is urging those who have been threatened or attacked in the past year to come forward with their stories.
The organization, which has over 5 million members, also announced a new initiative that will help individuals affected by discrimination in the United States. This includes providing legal aid and support services to victims of hate crimes, as well as offering counseling and education programs aimed at preventing future incidents of discrimination.
In addition to these efforts, the NAACP has launched a social media campaign called #NotYourRace, which encourages people to share personal stories of racial injustice on platforms like Twitter and Instagram. The hashtag was created in response to the recent deaths of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, and Ahmaud Arbery, three Black Americans who were killed by police officers while trying to exercise their First Amendment rights to freedom of speech and assembly.
The NAACP's new initiative is just one part of a larger movement to address systemic racism in America. In June, President Joe Biden signed an executive order directing federal agencies to review and revise civil rights laws to better protect marginalized
reference: Die Nationale Vereinigung zur Förderung von Farbigen hat eine Warnung für farbige Menschen ausgestellt, die aufgrund der diskriminierenden Politik und der rassistischen Angriffe des Staates nach Missouri reisen.

source: "The NAACP Travel Advisory for the state of Missouri, effective through August 28th, 2017, calls for African American travelers, visitors and Missourians to pay special attention and exercise extreme caution when traveling throughout the state given the series of questionable, race-based incidents occurring statewide recently, and noted therein," the group's statement reads.
translation_clean:
Translate the following text from en to de: "The NAACP Travel Advisory for the state of Missouri, effective through August 28th, 2017, calls for African American travelers, visitors and Missourians to pay special attention and exercise extreme caution when traveling throughout the state given the series of questionable, race-based incidents occurring statewide recently, and noted therein," the group's statement reads. The travel advisory also advises that all travelers should be aware of potential security threats in certain areas and refrain from visiting those areas at this time.

source: A recent Missouri law making it harder for people to win discrimination lawsuits, as well as the state's law enforcement disproportionately targeting minorities prompted the group to issue the travel alert, the NAACP said.

reference: Ein kürzlich verabschiedetes Gesetz von Missouri, das es Menschen schwerer macht, Diskriminierungsklagen zu gewinnen, sowie die Strafverfolgungsbehörden des Staates, die unverhältnismäßig auf Minderheiten abzielen, veranlassten die Gruppe, die Reisewarnung herauszugeben, sagte die NAACP.

The president of the Missouri NAACP, Rod Chapel, spoke with reporters about recent incidents involving police and African Americans in the state.
Chapel said that he has received a number of complaints from members of his organization about police misconduct and racial profiling. He also stated that he had seen some officers use excessive force on Black people during confrontations.
He added that there are no easy answers to these issues, but he hopes that this situation will bring attention to them.
Chapel's comments come as tensions between law enforcement agencies and communities continue to rise across the United States.
In a statement released by the NAACP on Thursday, the organization called for increased accountability and transparency in policing practices.
"Law enforcement must be held accountable for actions taken against our community, especially when it comes to race-based discrimination," the statement reads.
It's clear that the issue of racism and police brutality continues to be a pressing concern for many Americans.
President Barack Obama expressed his support for the movement to end systemic racism and police violence at a rally
reference: Sie werden wegen ihrer Hautfarbe angehalten, sie werden zusammengeschlagen oder getötet", sagte der Präsident des Missouri NAACP, Rod Chapel, dem Kansas City Star.

source: It is the first such warning that the organization has issued for a state in the US.
translation_clean:
Translate the following text from en to de: It is the first such warning that the organization has issued for a state in the US. The US government has been warned before about its failure to meet the minimum standards of human rights.
This means that, as far as we know, this is the first time that the United States federal government has received an official notification or letter regarding the failure to uphold the basic human rights and civil liberties guaranteed by international law.
In other words, the US government has not yet been officially informed about the ongoing violation of these rights.
The fact that the organization issuing the warning comes from the International Commission of Jurists (ICJ) is significant because it suggests that the ICJ might be considering whether the United States' actions are in line with international law.
It's worth noting that the International Commission of Jurists is a non-governmental organization, which means that they do not have any political influence over governments like the UN does.
Therefore, their warnings should be taken seriously by all parties involved.
So what is the significance of this warning? Does it indicate that the United States is violating the human rights and civil liberties of its citizens?
Or could it simply be a sign of growing concern among human rights organizations about the situation in the United States?
To
reference: Es ist die erste solche Warnung, die die Organisation für einen Staat in den USA ausgestellt hat.

source: The surest mark of regime change is when they start attacking the statues.
translation_clean: In this sentence, "statues" refers to historical monuments or memorials. The phrase "start attacking the statues" indicates that the government has taken action against these monuments, possibly by destroying them. This suggests a shift in power or leadership, as it implies that the new administration does not value the past and cultural heritage of the nation. By removing or damaging historical monuments, the new government is attempting to erase or diminish the importance of its predecessors' legacies and contributions. Consequently, the citizens feel reassured because they believe that the current government prioritizes respecting and honoring their shared history and cultural identity over any previous administrations. In essence, the removal of historical monuments serves as an indicator of regime change since it demonstrates a fundamental alteration in governance and national sentiment. Additionally, the statement highlights the significance of preserving historical monuments and the potential
reference: Das sicherste Zeichen eines Regime-Wechsels ist es, wenn sie beginnen, die Statuen zu attackieren.
